body:
This is directly related to some discussions I've had with people internally about if this is appropriate to do in Druid, or is better handled at a layer above Druid.

If the data mapping / concat has a direct manipulation of the results of the data (like how QTL can merge multiple IDs together) then it is an obvious candidate for a feature in druid.

But just like Druid isn't really an ETL engine for data coming in, I'm not convinced it is always a good candidate for ETL going out.

I _CAN_  see where maintaining access to lookups might be cumbersome if it has to be maintained in both Druid and an external system though. Especially if the lookup isn't a simple "query some DB and get a value for some ID". So I think having some kind of _ease-of-use_ and _operational-sanity_ capacity to have some form of "dimension explosion via lookups" at the query level for druid makes sense.

IMO something like this makes sense in Druid, it's always possible for functions to map things to a smaller output space, and pushing that down as far as possible will help performance and memory use.

Functionally, how does 

``` json
  "dimension": {    
    "outputName": "place",
    "type": "multi",
    "fn": "sprintf",
    "string": "%s->%s",
    "args": [
      "country",
      "city"
    ]
  },
```

Differ from a groupBy? (other than adding a sprintf on top of the results?)

One difference is that if Druid can treat that as a single column then we can do topNs on it.

Another difference is that we can filter on it. Even for simple stuff like "concat" it's annoying to write a filter without this functionality. You have to translate `WHERE CONCAT(a, b) = "foo"` to `WHERE (a = "" AND b = "foo") OR (a = "f" AND b = "oo") OR (a = "fo" AND b = "o") OR (a = "foo" AND b = "")`. For more complex functions it's not in general feasible to translate them to boolean filters.

IMO this feature is not super useful if it doesn't work with stuff like topNs and filters, but it really should.

Obviously (you know me) I would love to have a JS function that I can prototype / gap fill with that takes multiple inputs:

```
"dimension": {    
  "outputName": "place",
  "type": "multi-javasctipt",  
  "args": [
    "city",
    "region",
    "country"    
  ],
  "fn": "function(a,b,c) { return a || b || c; }"
}
```

in fact the JS functionality alone would make me happier than a pup with two tails.

@gianm It's a _hack_ solution for one of our realtime cases. We use druid to consume a streaming job's output to calculate some metrics like PV which is obviously sum(each_pv). But it's difficult to let the streaming job output each record exactly once because failover always exists. So we add a primary key to the event and make it dimension. Now we can use LongMax to dedup the duplicated events, and use LongSum to query.
@gianm this is failing UT
fixed
do you have this fix https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2952 ?

So right now we have the following capabilities regarding dimensionality of the data:
1. Project a single dimension onto another dimension basis (single-dimension lookups which are many-to-one or one-to-one).
2. Use combinations of dimension values. (group-by)

This ask, if I'm reading the discussion correctly, is to allow more flexibility along the lines of 1 by allowing a lookup (or some other dimension-function kind of feature) function's domain to have more than one dimension as input.

What this is NOT asking is to contain multiple values (one-to-many or many-to-many) in the range.

Is that accurate?

If so I think that's a reasonable ask so long as the use cases are reducing (or maintaining) overall datasource dimension value cardinality (ex: you can't get more rows out than are in the datasource ... also properly accounting for multi-value-dimension stuff)

we are using combination of string-math-expr(
https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2836) and virtual column (
https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2511) to address this kind of issue.
It looks something like "virtualColumns": [{"type": "expr", "expression":
"datediff(start, end)", "output": "time_diff"}], for example.

@drcrallen mostly looks good, a few comments to address and I can +1

Quick updates on the progress:

I now have a working prototype. There is a service that maintains a server view and returns a snapshot for the given query, which is similar to what #2282 does. And using the server view snapshot, Spark driver submits a Spark application that does something similar to what a Druid Broker does. If #2282 gets merged, I plan to eliminate the server view on my side and query Broker for the snapshot instead.

What the Spark driver and application do is to chunk the query into multiple parts (segments) and spawn multiple intermediate-level brokers that process a specific number of segments. And then the intermediate results get merged by the final stage broker. There is only one level of intermediate merging for now, but I might make the number of intermediate levels configurable. The number of segments that are queried simultaneously is configurable so I can control how many segments are queried at once to the historical nodes, instead of querying everything at once. It takes more time to get the results back from the spark-druid project due to the initialization time of Spark application and each Druid broker. However, query failure rate is very low compared to querying Druid broker (no OOMEs and timeouts). 

Currently, Spark drivers are run locally. Since Spark requires (or highly recommends) each SparkContext to be on separate JVM, my service spawns a new Java process for Spark Driver each time it receives a new query. This is fine for testing purpose, but not too good for production. My next step is to integrate it with Mesos so Spark driver for Druid queries can be run on Mesos and I wouldn't have to worry about managing resources.
We have problems with this.  We are using Hadoop 2.6.0 from Cloudera, and these dependencies conflict with the ones I am configuring via `hadoopDependencyCoordinates`.

@ottomata please see http://druid.io/docs/0.9.0/operations/other-hadoop.html

I think your issue may be different than the one described here
@jisookim0513 it sounds then like you went with approach (1)?

Naw, I've worked around that by setting `-Dhadoop.mapreduce.job.user.classpath.first=true`, so I'm not having explicit Jackson issues.  It's been a few hours since I worked around this issue by replacing the hadoop dependencies in `druid-hdfs-storage` with my versions.  I'll try to get a descriptive error for ya next week (gotta run soon!).

@gianm indeed, we started with the first approach since most of that work is a pre-requisite to get the second one working. So far that seems to solve our use-case, so unless we have issues with it, we probably won't go down the second option.

I wonder if we could define a new type of node, say "tiered-broker" which splits input query (by query interval) and forward the splitted query to regular druid broker, then merges (probably simply concatenates) results from downstream brokers and streams the whole resultset to user.
That would be same approach minus spark and mesos.
@himanshug such a thing would also be handy for large number of peons.

@jisookim0513 thanks for the update, this sounds awesome! Is there ability for a user to skip the final merging and just get an rdd that one could do any further work on?

@himanshug I think we could do tiered-brokers but that's separate. IMO getting the data into Spark is nice in and of itself, since it means a user can do further processing there in a distributed way, instead of streaming results out directly to/through a single machine.

Some more benchmarks, this time on a c4.8xlarge with a 31 thread processing pool, varying the number of segments to see how well the concurrent merging scales. It looks like neither the old or new approach scales perfectly, but the new one does scale better.

@gianm benchmarks look great!

this is really promising
👍  but I didn't read the tests very carefully

@gianm sure, I will have to refactor the code but you can get an RDD consisting of query results which would allow further processing such as join (although the result might not be accurate in some cases).
@drcrallen can we name the artifact id to something like `druid-globalCached-lookups` ? like that the second module will be called `druid-singleCached-lookups` ?
@skilledmonster  hahaha and How did you solve this one now ? well I found that the overlord and service names must match. but not working as of now.
@b-slim renamed to `lookups-cached-global`

minor comments but overall 👍

@fjy @pjain1 @navis Any more comments ?
LGTM, 👍 after fixing handling for parse exceptions (https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/3002#discussion_r64343356)

@erikdubbelboer We'd love to have direct GCS support without the overhead of maintaining a Hadoop cluster. #2645 already helps us quite a bit that we needn't keep scaling HDFS on our Data Proc cluster for historical segments. But this will allow us to even scale down the Hadoop nodes and not worry about affecting queries.

Hi, can you provide your ingestion spec as well?

> https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/3007
I need to do a short blurb about the QTL caching extension and incompatible changes. Will write when https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2926 is in master

This generally LGTM.  Charles' comment about totally removing the other two methods I think is legit.  I see two paths forward:
1. We could expand this PR to remove those methods as well and update all of the individual call sites.  That would mean that the PR cannot actually be merged until we have a backwards incompatible release, 'cause it's possible that someone has implemented their own Query flow.
2. We could accept this PR as is for now and essentially declare the `Segment` interface to be experimental and in-flux.  When we have it solidified, we do another PR to remove the other methods and declare things good.

I'm generally in favor of Option 1, if we are ok with doing a backwards incompatible release in the very near future (i.e. this gets merged without sitting here in the PR queue for a really long time).  If we are not ok with that, then I think we need to take approach 2.
@gianm not yet :)

I'm in favor of 2 for the time being, it seems more straightforward to merge that in for 0.9.2. Then once the interface changes have proven they can enable real world usage, we could do an expanded adjustment in the next major release.

- The prior `druid-namespace-lookup` extension has been moved to the Lookups framework and is now `druid-lookups-cached-global`. Documentation can be found at https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/master/docs/content/development/extensions-core/lookups-cached-global.md
- The prior `druid-kafka-extraction-namespace` has undergone some changes as well. Updated documentation is available at https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/master/docs/content/development/extensions-core/kafka-extraction-namespace.md

- A change was made to `QueryGranularity` to prevent a potential deadlock. A side effect is that most of the static fields are now in `QueryGranularities`. Please update any extensions accordingly. See https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2980
@drcrallen added to release notes. Can you edit them?

@fjy Yes, and I'll add directly to them if you want :) since you took initiative to write them up I
1. Didn't want to step on your toes with managing the release notes
2. Wanted to make the formatting pretty much done.

But If you want I can just edit the notes directly if I think of any more.

I can back this statement up:

> For block aggregation however, it is not enough to just loop-unroll. To achieve significant improvements, we also want to do block reads from the column and avoid materializing the filter offsets if possible.

I did test out what performance would be like if we only unrolled aggregator loops (but didn't do anything smart on the column-reading side, just looped over the existing Offset and column-reading interfaces). The speedup on a single-longSum-agg timeseries query was about 20%, which is good but not as good as the 60% that @xvrl got by also doing block reads and avoiding offset materialization.

Since @xvrl's implementation didn't support filters though, it remains to be seen where in between 20% and 60% we would end up with something that _does_ support filters but is also a bit smarter than just looping over the existing interfaces like I did.

I wasn't sure based on the discussion, but does the task priority implemented by this feature also control task execution order, or only the task locking stuff? (Execution order is what I really want to control)

Suggest this javadoc:

``` java
  /**
   * Request an implementation of a particular interface.
   *
   * If the passed-in interface is {@link QueryableIndex} or {@link StorageAdapter}, then this method behaves
   * identically to {@link #asQueryableIndex()} or {@link #asStorageAdapter()}. Other interfaces are only
   * expected to be requested by callers that have specific knowledge of extra features provided by specific
   * segment types. For example, an extension might provide a custom Segment type that can offer both
   * StorageAdapter and some new interface. That extension can also offer a Query that uses that new interface.
   *
   * @param clazz desired interface
   * @param <T> desired interface
   * @return instance of clazz, or null if the interface is not supported by this segment
   */
  public <T> T as(Class<T> clazz);
```

👍  otherwise.

@ryryguy Task Locking does not control execution order, its main purpose is to enable higher priority tasks to acquire a lock even when a lower priority task already has it by revoking the lower priority task lock.

In addition to what @gian wrote, please add something to the effect of

```
Implementations which accept classes other than {@link QueryableIndex} or {@link StorageAdapter} are limited to using those classes within the extension. This means that one extension cannot rely on the `Segment.as` behavior of another extension.
```

Could you please add docs for how to use this feature?
